sections.title:
On Justification of General Polynomial Projection
Method for Solving Periodic Fractional Integral Equations
sections.abstract:
IIn this paper we subtantiate a general polynomial projection
method for solving periodic integral equations with Holder coefficients
and fractional integral Weyl operator in the main part
sections.author: J.R. \, Agachev, A.F. \, Galimyanov
sections.keywords:
Holder space, integral equations, fractional integral,
trigonometric approximation
main_part:
1.1. \ Let $C \equiv C_{2\pi}$ be the space of continuous
$2\pi$-periodic functions with the usual $\max$-norm $\|\cdot\|_C$.
We denote by $H_\delta \; (0<\delta \leq 1)$ the space of
$2\pi-$ periodic functions satisfying Holder condition with an
exponent $\delta>0$ with the norm
$\|\varphi\|_{\delta}=\|\varphi\|_C + H(\varphi; \delta)$,
where $H(\varphi; \delta)$ is the smallest Holder constant. Next,
$H_{0, \delta}$ will stand for a subspace of the space $H_\delta$ of functions
$f(x)$, for which one has $\int\limits_0^{2\pi}f(x)\, dx = 0$.


We have the following (see, e.g., in \cite{samko}, p.~366, the
corollary of theorem 19.8)

\textbf{Lemma 1.}{\it Let $0 <\beta <1-\alpha $. Then the operator $G$
reflects isomorphically $H_{0, \beta}$ onto $H_{0, \alpha + \beta} $.}
Lemma 1 means that the operator $G$, as an operator acting from $H_{0, \beta}$ to
$H_{0, \alpha + \beta} $, is continuously invertible if $\beta \in
(0,1- \alpha)$.

For an arbitrarily fixed number $\beta, 0 <\beta <1- \alpha,$
let us fix two spaces: $\Phi = H_{\beta} \times \mathbb{R}^1,
F = H_{\alpha + \beta}$. The norm in $\Phi$ is given by the formula
$\|\overline{\varphi}\|_\Phi=|\gamma|+\|\varphi\|_\beta$, where
$\overline{\varphi}=(\varphi;\gamma)\in \Phi$.

Consider the operator $\overline{G}$ defined by the following relation:
$$
\overline{G} \overline{\varphi} \equiv \gamma + G \varphi, \quad
\overline{\varphi} = (\varphi; \gamma) \in \Phi. \eqno (3)
$$
Clearly, $ \overline{G}: \Phi \rightarrow F $. Let
$ \widetilde{\Phi} \subset \Phi $ be composed of elements of the form
$ (\widetilde{\varphi}; \gamma) $, where $ \widetilde{\varphi} \in
H_ {0, \beta} $.

\textbf{Lemma 2.}{\it For any $ \beta, 0 <\beta <1- \alpha, $
$ \overline{G}: \widetilde{\Phi} \rightarrow F $ is continuously invertible.}\textbf{Proof. } With any function $ f \in F $ we have
$$
f (x) = \widetilde{f} (x) + \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int \limits_0 ^ {2 \pi} f (t) \, dt,
\quad \widetilde{f} \in H_ {0, \alpha + \beta}.
$$
Therefore, by Lemma 1, there exists a unique function
$ \widetilde{\varphi} \in H_ {0, \beta} $ such that
$ G \widetilde{\varphi} = \widetilde{f} $. We thereby have
$$
\overline{\varphi} = (\widetilde{\varphi}; \gamma) \in
\widetilde{\Phi}, \quad
\gamma = \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int \limits_0 ^ {2 \pi} f (t) \, dt,\;
\overline{G} \overline{\varphi} \equiv \gamma + G \widetilde{\varphi} = f.
$$
Herewith
$
\| \overline{G} \overline{\varphi} \| \leq | \gamma
| + \| G \widetilde{\varphi} \| \leq | \gamma | + \| G \| \cdot
\| \widetilde{\varphi} \| _ \beta \leq \max (1; \| G \|) \cdot
\| \overline{\varphi} \| _ \Phi.
$
On the other hand, for an element $ \overline{\varphi}$ constructed on
an arbitrary function $f \in F$, we have
$\| \overline{\varphi} \| _ \Phi = \| \widetilde{\varphi} \| _ \beta + | \gamma | =
\| G ^ {- 1} \widetilde{f} \| _ \beta + | \gamma |$,
where $ \widetilde{f} = f- \gamma $. Consequently,
$$
\| \overline{\varphi} \| _ \Phi \leq
\| G ^ {- 1} \| _ {H_ {0, \alpha + \beta} \rightarrow H_ {0, \beta}} \cdot
\| \widetilde{f} \| _ {H _ {\alpha + \beta}} + | \gamma | \leq
%$$
%$$
%\leq 
\| G ^ {- 1} \| \cdot \| f \| _ {\alpha + \beta} + (\| G ^ {- 1} \| +1) \cdot
| \gamma |.
$$
This implies that
$$
\| \overline{\varphi} \| _ \Phi \leq \| G ^ {- 1} \| \cdot \| f \|
_ {\alpha + \beta} + (\| G ^ {- 1} \| +1) \cdot \| f \| _C \leq
%$$
%$$
%\leq 
(2 \| G ^ {- 1} \| +1) \cdot \| f \| _F, \; \overline{\varphi}
\in \widetilde{\Phi}, \, f \in F.
$$
Note that this estimate is valid if on the element
$ \overline{\varphi} \in \widetilde{\Phi} $ we construct an appropriate
function $f \in F$. Consequently, for the inverse operator we will have
$
\| \overline{G} ^ {- 1} \| _ {F \rightarrow \widetilde{\Phi}} \leq
2 \| G ^ {- 1} \| _ {H_ {0, \alpha + \beta} \rightarrow H_ {0, \beta}} + 1 <\infty,
0 <\beta <1- \alpha,
$
which completes the proof.

In what follows we will need the following (see in \cite{bgg70}, as
well as in \cite[p.~102, Lemma~3]{bgg80})

\textbf{Lemma 3.}{\it Let $ 0 <\beta <\mu <\infty $, the function $ f \in C $,
and a polynomial $ f_n \in \textbf{H} _n ^ T $ be such that
$\| f-f_n \| _C \leq c_1 n ^ {- \mu}$,
where $ c_1 $ is an absolute positive constant.

Then the inequality is valid:
$H (f-f_n; \beta) \leq c_2 n ^ {\beta- \mu}$,
where $ c_2 = c_2(\beta, \mu) $ is a positive constant independent of $n$.
}
From Lemma 3 the next result follows immediately.

\textbf{Corollary. }\it Under the conditions of Lemma 3 we have the estimate
$$
\| f-f_n \| _ \beta \leq c_3 n ^ {\beta- \mu}, \; c_3 = c_3 (\beta, \mu), \,
0 <\beta \leq 1, \beta <\mu.
$$\rm Consider the situation where a polynomial $ f_n $ in Lemma~3 is
constructed by using the operator $ P_n $ of the projection method.
In this siutation, the following result takes place:

\textbf{Lemma 4.}{\it Let $ 0 <\beta <\mu <\infty $, the function $ f \in
C $, and the operator $ P_n: C \rightarrow \textbf{H} _n ^ T $ be such that
such that
$
\| f-P_nf \| _C = O \left(n ^ {-\mu} \ln n\right).
$
Then 
$
\| f-P_nf \| _ \beta = O \left(n ^ {-\mu} \ln n\right)
$
for $ \beta \leq 1 $.}\textbf{Corollary. }\it If $ f \in H_ \mu, 0 <\beta <\mu \leq 1 $, and
operator $ P_n: C \rightarrow \textbf{H} _n ^ T $ possess the properties
$P_n ^ 2 = P_n, \; \| P_n \| _ {C \rightarrow C} = O (\ln n), n \rightarrow \infty$, then
$
\| f-P_nf \| _ \beta = O (n ^ {\beta- \mu}\ln n ), \; n \rightarrow
\infty.
$\rm Indeed, let $ \varepsilon> 0 $ be an arbitrary fixed number such that
$ \mu- \varepsilon> \beta $. Since $ \ln n $ tends to infinity slower
than any positive power of $n$, then for all $ n $ starting with a certain
one the following relation will be valid
$
\| f-P_nf \| _C = O \Bigl (n ^ {\varepsilon-\mu} \Bigr).
$
Then, by Lemma~3, for the smallest Holder constant there is fulfilled the order relation
$
H (f-P_nf; \beta) = O \Bigl (n ^ {\beta +\varepsilon-\mu} \Bigr)
$
and hence
$
\| f-P_nf \| _ \beta = O \Bigl (n ^ {-\mu} \ln
n + n ^ {\beta +\varepsilon-\mu} \Bigr).
$
Now the arbitrary $ \varepsilon $ can be chosen as being equal to
$\varepsilon = \varepsilon_n = \ln \ln n/\ln n $.
Then we obtain
$
\| f-P_nf \| _ \beta = O \Bigl (n ^ {\beta-\mu} \ln n \Bigr), \;
n \rightarrow \infty.
$
Further, as a result, by Jackson's -- Korneychuk's theorem (see, e.g.,
in \cite[p.~59]{daug} we have
$$
\| f-P_nf \| _C \leq (1+ \| P_n \| _ {C \rightarrow C}) E_n ^ T (f) \leq
%$$
%$$
%\leq 2 
\| P_n \| _ {C \rightarrow C} \cdot M_f \left (\pi/(n + 1) \right) ^ \mu = O \left (n ^{-\mu} \ln n \right) \,
,
$$
where $ M_f $ is a Holder continuous function $ f \in H_ \mu $.

\textbf{Note. }\it The assertion of Lemma 4 can be enhanced by applying
the condition of convergence to zero of the value  $\| f-P_nf \| _C
$ in terms for best uniform approximation of function $f$ by
trigonometric polynomials. Then the corollary will obtain a certain
generalization, which in some cases is required in justifying
specific projection methods for solving linear equations.

\medskip

\rm
2.1. \ Let us include the equation (1) to a wider class of equations of the form
$$
\overline{K} \overline{\varphi} \equiv \gamma +
\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int \limits_ {0} ^ {2 \pi} \Psi _ {\pm} ^ \alpha
(xt) \varphi (t) \, dt + (V \varphi) (x) = f (x), \quad - \infty <x <\infty,
$$
where $ \gamma \in \mathbb{R}^1, \overline{\varphi} = (\varphi;
\gamma) $. Considering  this equation in the two spaces $ (\Phi, F) $,
introduced above, we can write it out in the operator form:
$$
\overline{K} \overline{\varphi} \equiv \overline{G} \overline{\varphi}
+ V \varphi = f \quad (\overline{\varphi} = (\varphi; \gamma) \in \Phi, \,
f \in F). \eqno (1')
$$
Let $ P_n $ be an arbitrarily fixed projection operator $ F $ on $
F_n = \textbf{H}_n^T $, where $ \textbf{H}_n^T $ is the set of
trigonometric polynomials of orders not exceeding $ n $, and $ \Phi_n =
\{\overline{\varphi}_n = (\varphi_n; \gamma_n) \in F_n \times
\mathbb{R}^1 \} $. Then the projection method for solving the
equation ($1'$) defined by the operator $ P_n $ is given by the relation:
$$
\overline{K}_n \overline{\varphi} _n \equiv P_n \overline{K}
\overline{\varphi}_n = P_nf \quad (\overline{\varphi}_n \in \Phi_n).
\eqno (4)
$$
Note that, if the operator $ P_n $ is projectional, then
equation~(4) has the form
$$
\overline{K}_n \overline{\varphi}_n \equiv \overline{G}
\overline{\varphi}_n + P_nV \varphi_n = P_nf \quad
(\overline{\varphi}_n \in \Phi_n). \eqno (4')
$$\textbf{Note. }\it In some cases the direct method is constructed as($4'$) from
the beginning. Then the operator $ P_n $ is not required to possess the
projectional property. This allows us to get stronger results,
following from Lemma~3 (see, e.g., theorem formulated below~1).

\smallskip\rm 2.2. \ Let us start our considerations with the case where the operator $
V $ maps $ H_\beta $ into  $ H_{0, \alpha + \beta} $. Note that, if
in equation ($1'$) the right-hand side $f$ also belongs to the space
$ H_{0, \alpha + \beta} $, then we have $ \gamma = 0 $, and therefore the
projection method (4) for ($1'$) coincides with the general polynomial
projection method for solving equation (1), which has been already
studied in the paper~\cite{ag_gal1}.

\textbf{Theorem 1.}{\it Suppose that the following assumptions are true:

1) \ function $ f \in H_{\lambda}, \alpha + \beta <\lambda \leq 1 $;

2) \ operator $ V \,: \, \Phi \rightarrow H_{0, \lambda} $ is
continuous;

3) \ equation ($1'$) for $ f = 0 $ has solely the trivial solution;

4) \ operator $P_n$ is projectional, it is limited in the
space of continuous functions for every fixed $ n $,
and $ \| P_n \|_{C \rightarrow C} = O(\ln n), n \rightarrow \infty $.

Then the equation ($4'$) has unique solution $ \overline{\varphi}_n^*
= (\varphi_n^*; \gamma_n^*) $ (at least for all $n$ starting with a certain
natural one). The approximate solutions $\overline{\varphi}_n^* =
(\varphi_n^*; \gamma_n^*) $ converge to the exact solution $
\overline{\varphi}^* = (\varphi^*; \gamma^*) $ of ($1'$) in the
space $ \Phi $ at the rate of
$$
\| \overline{\varphi}^* - \overline{\varphi}_n^* \|_\Phi=O \bigl(n^{\alpha +
\beta-\lambda} \ln n \bigr). \eqno (5)
$$
}\rm Indeed, if ($ 1 '$) has a solution
$ \overline{\varphi} = (\varphi; \gamma) $, then
$ \gamma = \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_0 ^ {2 \pi} f (t) \, dt $ and, therefore,
$ \varphi $ is a solution of
$K \varphi = \widetilde{f}, \; \widetilde{f} \in H_{0, \alpha + \beta}$.
Thus, by Lemma 1, in that case, the solution of ($1'$)
might be only an element $ \overline{\varphi} \in \widetilde{\Phi} $.
The latter means that the projection method (4) for equation ($1'$)
coincides with the projection method for equation (1) with the right-hand side
$ f \in \widetilde{\Phi} $.

Thus, in this case, the theorem follows from the results in the paper
article~\cite{ag_gal1}. Herewith, we have $\gamma^* = (2\pi)^{-1}
\int_0^{2\pi} f(t) \, dt$.

2.4. \ Now let us consider the case where $ V: H_\beta \rightarrow
H_{\alpha + \beta} $ is an integral operator of the form
$$
(V \varphi) (x) = \int\limits_0^{2 \pi} v(x, t) \varphi(t) \, dt, \eqno(6)
$$
where the kernel $v(x, t)$ is $2\pi$-periodic uniformly with respect
to each of variables.


\textbf{Theorem 2.}{\it Suppose that the following assumptions are true:

1) \ the function $f \in H_{\lambda}, \alpha + \beta <\lambda \leq 1 $;

2) \ $v \in H_\lambda $ with respect to $x$, $v \in L_1(0,2\pi)$ and
odd with respect to $t$;

3) \ the equation ($1'$), (6) is uniquely solvable for any right-hand
part from $F$;

4) \ the operator $P_n$ is projectional, limited in the
space of continuous functions for any fixed  $n$, and
$ \| P_n \|_{C \rightarrow C} = O(\ln n), n \rightarrow \infty $.

Then the equation (4) for all sufficiently large $n$ is uniquely
solvable. Approximate solutions, found by (4), do converge
to the exact solution of the equation ($1'$) in the space $ \Phi $ with the
rate of~(5). }\textbf{Proof. }\rm First of all, we notice that, under conditions of
theorem, for an arbitrary function $ \varphi \in H_\beta $, we will have the equality:
$V \varphi = V \widetilde{\varphi}, \quad G \varphi = G \widetilde{\varphi}$,
where $ \widetilde{\varphi} = \varphi
- (2 \pi)^{-1} \int_0^{2 \pi} \varphi \, dt $. Therefore, the equation ($1'$)
and the equation of projection method ($ 4'$) are of the form:
$$
\overline{K} \widetilde{\overline{\varphi}} \equiv \overline{G}
\widetilde{\overline{\varphi}} + V \widetilde{\varphi} = f \quad
(\widetilde{\overline{\varphi}} \in \widetilde{\Phi}), \eqno (1'')
$$$$
\overline{K}_n \widetilde{\overline{\varphi}}_n \equiv \overline{G}
\widetilde{\overline{\varphi}}_n + P_nV \widetilde{\varphi}_n
= P_nf \quad (\widetilde{\overline{\varphi}}_n \in
\widetilde{\Phi}_n). \eqno(4'')
$$
Since, by Lemma 2, the operator
$ \overline{G}: \widetilde{\Phi} \rightarrow F $ is continuously invertible and
$ V: H_\beta \rightarrow F $ is compact, we have that the existence of the unique solution
of the equation ($ 1'$) (6) for any right-hand side $ F $ is equivalent to
the invertibility of the continuous operator
$ \overline{K}: \widetilde{\Phi} \rightarrow F $.

Furthermore, uder the assumptions 4), we have
$
\| f-P_nf \|_C \leq 2 \, \| P_n \|_{C \rightarrow C} \cdot E_n^T(f) = O \{n^{- \lambda} \ln n \},
$
where $ E_n^T(f) $ is the best uniform approximation of function $ f(x)$
by trigonometric polynomials of an order not exceeding $n $.
Then, by virtue of the corollary to Lemma~4, we can easily deduce the proximity
of the right-hand sides of equations ($ 1''$) and ($4''$):
$
\delta_n \equiv \| f-P_nf \|_F = O \{n^{\alpha + \beta- \lambda}
\ln n \} \rightarrow 0, \; n \rightarrow \infty.
$
Now let us determine the proximity of the operators in ($ 1''$) and ($ 4'' $).
To this end, for an arbitrary
$ \overline{\widetilde{\varphi}}_n \in \widetilde{\Phi}_n $ we consider the
difference
$ \overline{K} \overline{\widetilde{\varphi}}_n-
\overline{K}_n \overline{\widetilde{\varphi}}_n $. We thus have
$$
\| \overline{K} \overline{\widetilde{\varphi}}_n- \overline{K}_n
\overline{\widetilde{\varphi}}_n \|_F = \| V \widetilde{\varphi}_n -
P_nV \widetilde{\varphi}_n \| =O\{\ln n \cdot E_n^T(V \widetilde{\varphi}_n) \}=
$$$$
 O \{\ln n \cdot
E_n^{Tx}(v)_{C \times L_1} \| \widetilde{\varphi}_n \|_C \} =
O \{n^{\alpha + \beta- \lambda} \ln n \} \|
\widetilde{\varphi}_n \|_\beta,
$$
where $ E_n^{Tx}(v)_{C \times L_1} $ is the quotient of the best
approximation of the kernel  $ v(x, t) $ on the variable  $ x $ by
trigonometric polynomials of order not exceeding $ n $ in a mixed metric.
Thus, $\varepsilon_n \equiv \| \overline{K} - \overline{K}_n
\|_{\widetilde{\Phi} \rightarrow F} = O \{n^{\alpha + \beta-
\lambda}\ln n \}$.

The rest is obvious if one considers theorem~7 of chapter~I in
mono\-graph~\cite{bgg80}.

\smallskip\textbf{Note. }\it The kernel of the integral operator $ V $ might be
differential. In this case, obviously, the function $ v $(of a single argument)
must be odd and must belong to $ L_1 $.

\rm
2.5. \ Let us consider the case, where the operator $V: H_\beta \rightarrow
H_{\alpha + \beta} $ is continuous and small by norm.

\textbf{Theorem 3.}{\it Suppose that the following assumptions are true:

1) \ function $ f \in H_{\lambda}, \alpha + \beta <\lambda \leq 1 $;

2) \ operator $ V\, :\,  \Phi \rightarrow H_\lambda $ is continuous,
and
$ \| V \|_{H_\beta \rightarrow F} <\| G^{- 1} \|_{H_ {0, \alpha
+ \beta} \rightarrow H_{0, \beta}}^{- 1};
$

3) \ operator $ P_n $ is projectional, limited in space of
continuous functions for each fixed $ n $, and $ \| P_n \|_{C
\rightarrow C} = O (\ln n), n \rightarrow \infty $.

Then the equation (4) has a unique solution, at least for all $ n $
sufficiently large. The approximate solutions, as soon as being found by
(4), do converge to the exact solution of the equation ($ 1'$) in
the space $ \Phi $ with the rate
$
\| \overline{\varphi} - \overline{\varphi}_n \|_\Phi = O
\bigl(n^{\alpha +\beta-\gamma} \ln n \bigr).
$
}\textbf{Proof. } We take into account that,  for any $ \varphi \in
H_\beta $$ G \varphi = G \widetilde{\varphi} $, where
$ \widetilde{\varphi} = \varphi - (2 \pi)^{-1} \int_0^{2 \pi} \varphi \,
dt $, the equation ($ 1'$) can be written out in the form
$
\overline{K} \overline{\varphi} \equiv \overline{G}
\widetilde{\overline{\varphi}} + V \varphi = f \quad
(\widetilde{\overline{\varphi}} \in \widetilde{\Phi}).
$
By Lemma 2, the operator $ \overline{G}: \widetilde{\Phi} \rightarrow F $
has a continuous inverse $ \overline{G}^{- 1}: F \rightarrow
\widetilde{\Phi} $. By applying it to the last equation, we obtain
the following second kind equation:
$$
\overline{K}_1 \overline{\varphi} \equiv
\widetilde{\overline{\varphi}} + \overline{G}^{- 1} V \varphi
= \overline{G}^{- 1} f \quad (\widetilde{\overline{\varphi}} \in
\widetilde{\Phi}). \eqno(7)
$$
Since
$
\| \overline{G}^{- 1} V \| _ {H_\beta \rightarrow \widetilde{\Phi}} \leq
\| \overline{G}^{- 1} \|_{F \rightarrow \widetilde{\Phi}} \cdot
\| V \| _ {H_\beta \rightarrow F} <1.
$
The Banach's theorem on the perturbation of the identity operator with a
small norm (see, e.g., in~\cite[p.~140]{trenog}) gives us that the
equation~(7) has a unique solution $ \overline{\varphi}^* =
(\varphi^*; \gamma^*) \in \Phi $. The latter means that the equation ($1'$)
(equivalent to (7)) also has the unique solution $ \overline{\varphi}^* $.
Moreover, the operator $ \overline{K} = \overline{G} \,
\overline{K}_1: \Phi \rightarrow F $ is continuously invertible:
$
\| \overline{K}^{- 1} \|_{F \rightarrow \Phi} \leq
\| \overline{G}^{- 1} \|_{F \rightarrow \widetilde{\Phi}} \cdot
\| \overline{K}_1^{- 1} \|_{\widetilde{\Phi} \rightarrow \Phi} <\infty.
$
Now let us show that the equation of the projection method (4) will also
have a unique solution, for at least sufficiently large $n$. To this end we
verify the conditions of Theorem~7 from chapter~I of monograph~\cite{bgg80},
which gives us sufficient conditions for convergence of  the direct method for
solving the equation~($ 1'$).

We have (see proof of Theorem~2)
$$
\delta_n \equiv \| f-P_nf \|_F = O \{n^{\alpha + \beta- \lambda}
\ln n \} \rightarrow 0, \; n \rightarrow \infty. \eqno(8)
$$
Furthermore, for any element $ \overline{\varphi}_n \in \Phi_n,
\overline{\varphi}_n \ne 0 $$
\| \overline{K} \overline{\varphi}_n-
\overline{K}_n \overline{\varphi}_n \| _F = \| V {\varphi}_n -
P_nV{\varphi}_n \| =
 \| \varphi_n \|_\Phi \cdot \| V {\psi}_n - P_nV {\psi}_n \|, \;
\psi_n = \varphi_n / \| \varphi_n \|_\Phi.
$
The latter implies that
$
\| \overline{K} \overline{\varphi}_n-
\overline{K}_n \overline{\varphi}_n \|_F \leq \| \varphi_n \|_\Phi \cdot
\sup_{g \in VS (0, 1)} \, \| g - P_ng \|_F,
$
where $S(0, 1)$ is the unit ball centered at the origin of the space $\Phi $.
Thus, taking into account the limit relation (8), we obtain:
(see. also our work ~\cite{ag_gal1})
$$
\varepsilon_n \equiv \| \overline{K} - \overline{K}_n \|_{\Phi \rightarrow
F} \leq \sup_{g \in VS (0, 1)} \, \| g - P_ng \|_F \rightarrow 0, \;
n \rightarrow \infty.
$$
The resting arguments follow from Theorem~7 and Theorem~6 on
representation of error of approximate solutions in the
monograph~\cite[p.~17]{bgg80}.

\smallskip\textbf{Notes. }\it 1. From the research mentioned above in
paragraphs 2.2--2.5 the convergence of polynomial collocation methods
and subdomains with equally spaced nodes follow.

2. If in the capacity of equation of projection method one takes the equation ($4'$),
then the operator $ P_n $, as has been noted above, might possess no property of
projection; however the convergence of the method will take place.
A sufficient condition for that is as follows:
$
\| f-P_nf \|_F \rightarrow 0, \; n \rightarrow \infty,
$
for any function $ f \in H_\lambda, \alpha + \beta <\lambda \leq 1 $. This
provides the justification of the method in the case, when in capacity of $ P_n $
yje polynomial operators constructed on the base of summation of the Fourier
series are taken.

\rm
Here we will dweel here only in the case where the operator  $ P_n $ in the space of
continuous functions has good approximating properties. In this case, we will try to receive
the results for total polynomial projection method (4).

The following assertion holds true:

\textbf{Theorem 4.}{\it Suppose that the following assumptions are true:

1) \ function $ f \in H_{\lambda}, \alpha + \beta <\lambda \leq 1 $;

2) \ operator $ V \,: \, \Phi \rightarrow H_\lambda $ is
continuous;

3) \ equation ($ 1'$) for $ f = 0 $ has only the trivial solution;

4) \ operator $ P_n $ in the space of continuous functions has
property: \ for any function $ g \in C $ \quad
$
\| g-P_ng \|_C = O(E_n^T (g)), \; n \rightarrow \infty.
$

Then the equation (4) has a unique solution for all sufficiently large $n$.
The approximate solutions, which have been found by (4), converge to
the exact solution of the equation ($ 1'$) in the space $ \Phi
$ with the rate
$\| \overline{\varphi} - \overline{\varphi}_n \|_\Phi = O \bigl(n^{\alpha
+ \beta - \gamma} \bigr)$.
}\textbf{Proof. }\rm First, we should note that under the conditions
of Theorem, the proximity of right-hand sides of equations ($ 1'$) and
(4) in the space $ F $ is obvious since (see as well the proof of
theorem~2) $\| f-P_nf \|_C = O (E_n^T(f)) = O (n^{- \lambda})$.

To prove the proximity of the operators of our equations, we take an arbitrary
element  $ \overline{\varphi}_n \in \Phi_n, \overline{\varphi}_n
\ne 0 $, and consider
$
\| \overline{K} \overline{\varphi}_n-
\overline{K}_n \overline{\varphi}_n \|_F = \| \overline{\varphi}_n \|_\Phi \cdot
\| \overline{K} \overline{\psi}_n-
\overline{K}_n \overline{\psi}_n \|_F,
$
where
$ \overline{\psi}_n = \overline{\varphi}_n / \| \overline{\varphi}_n \|_\Phi =
(\psi_n, \widetilde{\gamma}_n) $. Then
$$
\| \overline{K} \overline{\varphi}_n-
\overline{K}_n \overline{\varphi}_n \|_F =
\| \overline{\varphi}_n \|_\Phi \cdot \| K \psi_n-P_nK \psi_n \|_F,
\eqno(9)
$$
where $K$ is the operator in equation (1).

Based on both the assumption 4) of he theorem and the properties of the best uniform
approximations by trigonometric polynomials, we have
$$
\| K \psi_n-P_nK \psi_n \|_C = O \bigl (E_n^T (K \psi_n) \bigr) =
O \bigl (E_n^T (V \psi_n) \bigr), \, \overline{\psi}_n \in \Phi_n,
\| \overline{\psi}_n \| = 1,
$$
which implies immediately
$$
\| K \psi_n-P_nK \psi_n \|_C = O \Bigl \{\sup_{\overline{\psi} \in
\Phi, \| \overline{\psi} \| = 1} \, E_n^T (V \psi) \Bigr \} =  O
\Bigl \{\sup_{g \in H_\lambda} \, E_n^T(g) \Bigr \} = O(n^{-
\lambda}).
$$
Thus, from (9) and the last relation, it implies that
$
\| \overline{K} - \overline{K}_n \|_{\Phi \rightarrow F} = O
\Bigl\{n^{\alpha + \beta- \gamma} \Bigr\}.
$
The rest is obvious.

\textbf{Notes. }\it 1.  The results concerning the convergence of the
polynomial projection method will be significantly reinforced if the
coefficients have certain differential properties. In particular,
if the coefficients are such that the solution $x(t)$ has a
derivative of order $r \geq 1$  and  $x^{(r)} \in H_{\lambda}, 0
<\lambda \leq 1$, then constructing approximate solutions converge
to the exact one with a speed
$
\| \overline{\varphi}^*-\overline{\varphi}_n^*\|_\Phi =
O\bigl(n^{\alpha +\beta-r-\lambda} \ln n \bigr).
$
2. Proven theorem enables obtaining convergence of specific
projection methods for solving equations  ($ 1'$) and hence the
equation (1) constructed on the basis of a polynomial operator. In
particular, we directly obtain the convergence of projection methods
for solving equations ($ 1'$) with operators  $ P_n $, constructed
by means of summation of Fourier series (see for corresponding
computational schemes the our work~\cite{ag_gal1}).

\rm\medskip
